did.unittitle: Karl M. Waage Archives

repository.corpname: Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History

did.abstract: The archives of Karl M. Waage encompassing his career at Yale. These include annotated maps, field notebooks, photographs, correspondence, and biographical material.

prefercite.head: Cite As
prefercite.p: Karl M. Waage Archives, Invertebrate Paleontology, Yale Peabody Museum

bioghist.head: Biographical Sketch
bioghist.p: Karl M. Waage was born December 15, 1915, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Influenced early on by an amateur rock and mineral collector, he entered Princeton University in 1935 with an interest in geology. Having been introduced to the geology of the American West by Erling Dorf, Waage?s senior thesis was on the stratigraphy of the Upper Cretaceous Fox Hills Formation in the Lance Creek area of Wyoming.

Waage earned his Ph.D. from Princeton in 1946, with a dissertation on the refractory clays of the Lower Cretaceous Dakota Group of the Colorado Front Range. Hired that year by Yale University, he extended his work on the Dakota Group, clarifying its relationship to the underlying Morrison Formation, drawing attention to the importance of regional unconformities that represented significant time hiatuses, revising its stratigraphy, and providing an interpretation of its depositional environment.

In the mid-1950s, Waage refocused his attention on the Fox Hills Formation in its type area in South Dakota. His enthusiasm for this subject was to mark his research for the rest of his career. His field studies culminated in a 1968 monograph, The Type Fox Hills Formation, Cretaceous (Maestrichtian), South Dakota (Bulletin of the Peabody Museum of Natural History 27), describing the facies relationships, lithologic units, and molluscan zonation. He showed that this formation represented a transition from the environment of a clastic barrier shelf through that of the shoreface of a barrier bar complex during the final retreat of the Late Cretaceous sea.

This work set a standard for paleoenvironmental studies at a time when such studies were first gaining prominence. From the large, well-documented collections amassed during many field seasons, Waage, with his student Neil Landman, produced a monograph on the systematics, life history and distribution of the beautifully preserved scaphited ammonites.

Waage was Director of the Yale Peabody Museum from 1979 through 1982. He and Carl Dunbar wrote a textbook on historical geology, continuing a tradition begun by Charles Schuchert. Retiring in 1986, he wrote several more papers on scaphites and, in 1999, just before his death, co-authored a final manuscript on Holocene fossils from West Haven, Connecticut, a project he had begun 30 years earlier.

scopecontent.head: Description of the Material
scopecontent.p: Includes topographic maps (Colorado, Connecticut, New York, North Dakota, South Dakota, Wyoming) and other maps (North Dakota, South Dakota, Utah, Wyoming). Also includes field notebooks (Colorado, Maryland, New Jersey, New Mexico, North Dakota, South Dakota, Utah, Wyoming).

Photographs
Localities. Photographs, slides, & drawings of localities.

Photographs & Negatives. about 250 color 35 mm slides; Early Cretaceous "Dakota Grp" stratigraphy, Front Range, Colorado, Wyoming, Black Hills, South Dakota, and other strat. slides; several include shots of K.M.W.; many are originals of photos in publications (IP reprints 5026, 5027, 5061, 5062). Donated by Elizabeth Waage, July 18, 2001. 1951-1956
Photographs & Negatives. Black & White negatives & photos, Dakota Grp stratigraphy, Colorado, Wyoming, some published.
Photographs & Negatives. 4x5 Black & White photos of IP collection storage and work areas for several IP collection and facilities grants. 1960-1970
Photographs & Negatives. Black & white photographs & negatives & color sildes of localities, field work done on Fox Hills in South Dakota & Wyoming. Hickey. 1961-1985

Photographs. Photo and negative of field assistant with bra painted on him; sent to U.S.G.S. when they rejected nude-upper-body photo (also enclosed) for publication in Waage's Bull. 1102, Stratig. and refractory clayrocks of Dakota Grp... Colorado, plate 5; (reprint # IP.R.05027).
Photographs. color slides taken in 1961 by Leo J. Hickey, with list of slides and their field locations plotted on maps; Fox Hills Fm, S. & N. Dakota, Wyoming: photocopy of LH 1961 field notebook.
Specimens. Photographs & Slides of specimens.
Drawing. Original drawing by Carl Wester for illustration in "The Late Cretaceous coleoid cephalopod Actinosepia canadensis Whiteaves." YPM Postilla, n. 94.

Photographs & Negatives. 8 x 10 black and white print of YPM 1002, Dunbaria fascipennis Tillyard (partype). Replacement photo for Dunbar and Waage (Historical Geology, 3rd ed.) 8 x 10 black and white print. ca 1960

Photographs & Negatives. Black and white negatives and prints of Cretaceous ammonites (mostly scaphites) & other inverts & plants & concs. & lith structures; including the Yale and Princeton collections; for Jeletzky & Waage, 1978, Waage, 1968, & Landman & Waage, 1993; some U.S.G.S.; includes types of Meek, Owen, Mikhailov, Geol. Surv. Canada, Acad. Nat. Sci. Phil. black and white negatives and prints. 1960-1990

Photographs & Negatives. Black and white prints and negatives of various geological phenomena and fossils used for K.M. Waages historical geology textbook. Black and white prints and negatives. ca 1960
Photographs & Negatives. Black and white negatives and prints of Cretaceous coleoids(Actinosepia) Black and white negatives and prints
Photographs & Negatives. Black and White negatives & prints of Precambrian Ediacara (Australia) fauna for K.M. Waage's historical geology textbook
Photographs & Negatives. Photographs and negatives related to paper "Post-glacial fossils from Long Island Sound off West Haven, Connecticut" (YPM Postilla 225).
Photographs & Negatives. YPM 36058, Placenticeras whitfieldi. mososaur; limpet, 4x5 negative and six 8x10 black and white prints
Suite of ammonites (Scaphitidae and Sphenodiscus) from Fox Hills Fm showing brilliant nacreous color; 1 drawer's worth.
